titleStmt.title: Is Ureaplasma spp. the leading causative agent of acute chorioamnionitis in women with preterm birth?

analytic.title: Is Ureaplasma spp. the leading causative agent of acute chorioamnionitis in women with preterm birth?

biblStruct.note: Received 22 July 2016 Received in revised form 30 September 2016 Accepted 1 October 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: 16S rRNA Chorioamnionitis Fluorescence in situ hybridization Neonatal mortality Preterm birth Ureaplasma

p.s: Objectives: Aim of this study was to detect microorganisms in fetal membranes and placental tissue in preterm chorioamnionitis by combining fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) with broad range PCR.
The combination of the two molecular techniques enables identification and localization of the microorganisms within the tissue, confirming their clinical relevance.

Methods: In a prospective cohort study, we compared 31 women with preterm premature rupture of membranes or preterm labour and preterm delivery by caesarean section with a control group of 26 women undergoing elective caesarean section at term.
Fetal membranes and placental tissue were analysed by FISH and broad range 16S rRNA-gene PCR and sequencing.
Results: For 20 women in the preterm group, caesarean section was performed because of a clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis.
Microorganisms were detected in the tissues by both molecular techniques in 11 out of 20 women.
Among those, Ureaplasma spp. was most abundant, with five cases that remained culture-negative and would have been missed by routine diagnostic procedures.
Other infections were caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus mitis or Escherichia coli.
FISH and PCR were negative for all women without suspected chorioamnionitis and for the control group.
Conclusions: Combination of FISH with broad-range PCR and sequencing permitted unambiguous identification of the causative microorganisms in chorioamnionitis.
The high prevalence of Ureaplasma spp.
should lead to a re-evaluation of its clinical significance and possible therapeutic consequences.
Preterm birth is the main cause of perinatal mortality and morbidity worldwide [1,2].
Most spontaneous preterm deliveries follow preterm labour or preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM).
The causes are diverse, but microbial invasion of the amniotic cavity and intra-amniotic inflammatory processes are considered the leading aetiological factor [3].
Increasing use of molecular techniques has proven that culturebased methods lead to underestimation of the microbial species associated with preterm birth.
Mendz et al. [4] and DiGiulio [5] reviewed the diversity of microorganisms identified by amplification-based techniques in the uterine cavity and amniotic fluid in preterm birth.
The highest prevalence was shown for recognized genital pathogens, e.g.
Ureaplasma spp.
and Mycoplasma spp., as well as numerous species found in the oral and gastrointestinal microflora.
Polymicrobial colonization ranged from 24% to 67%.
The fastidious nature of most of these microorganisms and frequent antibiotic treatment hamper successful detection by cultural methods.
Also, uncultivated bacteria may be involved in the initiation of preterm birth [6].
However, molecular detection is prone to contamination by vaginal flora and has therefore to be interpreted with caution.
Most studies investigating the bacterial diversity associated with preterm birth focus on the examination of amniotic fluid [7,8] or fetal membranes and placental tissue [9,10].

Microbial invasion of the amniotic cavity is thought to play a key role in the aetiology of preterm labour and PPROM, although it is unclear whether bacterial colonization precedes or results from inflammation of the chorio-decidual interface [11,12].
Existing data about the prevalence of microorganisms in the amniotic cavity in the absence of any signs of infection are inconclusive.

In a study conducted by Steel et al. [13], bacteria were detected frequently in fetal membranes and placental tissue, including the majority of samples from term deliveries without preterm labour or PPROM.
In other investigations [9,11], samples taken from corresponding cases were shown to be negative by broad-range and species-specific PCR.
A non-infectious aetiology was assumed for most cases with acute histological chorioamnionitis at term [14].
These conflicting data can partially be explained by differences in patient groups, sample acquisition and technical approaches.
Fetal membranes and placental tissue obtained after vaginal delivery usually contain higher numbers of microorganisms, possibly resulting from bacterial colonization during labour.
Several methods for specimen preparation were developed to reduce the risk of contamination due to vaginal delivery [9,13,15].
Amplification-based techniques are highly sensitive but they do not provide information about the spatial distribution of bacteria or the predominant microorganism.
The combination of amplification-based techniques with fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) allows verification of the information obtained by PCR in situ.
Microorganisms can simultaneously be visualized and identified within the tissue [16].
FISH was successfully used to detect microorganisms in placental tissue, including species-specific detection of Fusobacterium nucleatum in fetal membranes after PPROM [17].
In a pilot study, a FISH probe panel was evaluated in two cases of acute chorioamnionitis, clarifying the pathogenic pathway for these women [18].

The aim of our study was to identify the clinically relevant microorganisms in fetal membranes and placental tissue leading to preterm birth using a combination of two molecular methods, broad range 16S rRNA-gene PCR and FISH.
We included only women delivering by caesarean section.
Results gained by molecular techniques were compared with routine culture, histopathology and clinical data to assess the clinical relevance of the microorganisms detected.
A prospective cohort study was conducted in the Department of Obstetrics at Charit e University Medicine, Campus Mitte, Berlin, Germany.
The study design and protocol were approved by the local ethics committee (EA2/043/13).
Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
The preterm group included 31 women with PPROM (n ¼ 21), preterm labour (n ¼ 6) and cervical incompetence (n ¼ 4).
All women had preterm deliveries by caesarean section.
The cases of two women (no.
6 and no.
8) have been published previously in a proof-of-principle study to establish the study protocol [18].
We recruited women consecutively, identified by clinical symptoms of preterm birth at admission (PPROM, preterm labour, cervical incompetence), and undergoing preterm caesarean section.
Indication for delivery was assessed for each woman.
Clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis was defined by persistent preterm labour in combination with at least one of the following criteria: maternal fever (>38.0
C), rising white blood cell count and Creactive protein or fetal tachycardia (>160 beats/min).
The control group included 26 women with elective caesarean section beyond 37 weeks of gestation.
Participants were recruited consecutively when undergoing elective caesarean section at term, in the absence of exclusion criteria.

Exclusion criteria for the control group were labour, rupture of membranes or any sign of infection at delivery or during the course of pregnancy, bacterial vaginosis, administration of antibiotics and intrauterine growth restriction.
In each case, five tissue samples were collected after caesarean section from fetal membranes, placental tissue and umbilical cord.
Samples were obtained intraoperatively under sterile conditions to minimize the risk of contamination, following a protocol established previously [18].
The tissue samples were analysed by two molecular techniques, FISH and 16S rRNA-gene PCR.
In parallel, swabs were taken from placenta and fetal membranes for microbial routine procedures including aerobic and anaerobic cultivation on agar plates and enrichment in thioglycollate broth.
Subsequently, placenta and fetal membranes were subjected to routine histopathological examination.

Clinical data concerning routinely taken prenatal microbial vaginal swabs, antibiotic treatment, neonatal outcome regarding signs of infection and systemic inflammatory response syndrome and postoperative maternal complications were assessed.
Sample preparation and FISH were performed as described previously [19].
Sections of tissue samples were first screened with the pan-bacterial, 16S rRNA directed probe EUB338 to detect microorganisms [20].
To exclude unspecific probe binding, positive signals were reviewed using the probe NONEUB (NON338) [21].
When microorganisms were detected, a panel of FISH probes was applied for identification on a genus-specific or species-specific level.
We used a probe panel established previously to identify microorganisms frequently associated with preterm birth [18] and a 23S rRNA directed, E. coli-species-specific probe [22].
Positive reference strains and negative control strains with mismatches in the target sequence were included in every hybridization experiment.
The nucleic acid stain DAPI (4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole) was applied to unspecifically visualize bacteria and cell nuclei.

Tissue sections consecutive to those used for FISH were submitted to DNA extraction with a commercially available specimen preparation kit (Amplicor; Roche Molecular Systems Inc, Branchburg, NJ, USA).
Broad-range PCR amplification and sequencing of part of the 16S rRNA-gene was performed as described previously [23].

The resulting sequences were compared to all currently available data from public databases (EMBL/GenBank) using the programs BLAST and FastA of the sequence analysis program HUSAR vs. 4.1 (Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany).
Samples positive for Ureaplasma spp.
were further analysed by a hybridization probe-based real-time PCR protocol targeting the urease gene (ureA) of Ureaplasma spp.

Differentiation of Ureaplasma urealyticum from Ureaplasma parvum was carried out by melting-curve analysis after PCR amplification on a Light-Cycler 2.0 platform (Roche Molecular Diagnostics, Pleasanton, CA, USA).
In total, 57 women were included in the study, 31 participants being recruited for the preterm group and 26 participants being enrolled in the control group.
The preterm group was divided into two subgroups (preterm subgroups I and II), depending on the indication for delivery.
In preterm subgroup I (20 cases), caesarean section was indicated because of clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis.
In preterm subgroup II (11 cases), delivery was indicated for other reasons (Table 1).

div.head: Identification of microorganisms in placenta and fetal membranes

p.s: In the preterm subgroup I, molecular techniques detected bacteria in 12 cases (Table 2).
Ureaplasma parvum/urealyticum was the most prevalent microorganism, with positive broad-range PCR and sequencing in five cases (nos 1e5).
These results were further confirmed by an independent Ureaplasma-specific real-time PCR, which identified U. parvum in all five cases.
As no Ureaplasma spp.specific

FISH probe was available, the Ureaplasma cells were visualized using the pan-bacterial probe EUB338 and the nucleic acid stain DAPI, revealing small intracellular microorganisms of the expected morphology and size of 0.1e1 mm diameter (Fig. 1).
These microorganisms tested negative with all species-specific FISH probes.
In further cases, molecular techniques and culture concordantly identified Staphylococcus aureus (nos 6 and 7, Fig. 2), Streptococcus mitis-group (nos 8 and 9) and Escherichia coli (nos 10 and 11).
The E. coli-specific FISH probe revealed bacteria only in case 11.
In case 10, FISH was negative with all probes but positive with the nucleic acid stain DAPI, indicating low ribosome content of the bacteria.
FISH and culture both stayed negative in case 12, whereas PCR amplification showed a faint band in agarose gel electrophoresis.
However, sequencing remained inconclusive.
In the preterm subgroup II, FISH and broad-range PCR showed negative results in all cases.
Culture was negative for nine women.
In one case with delivery at 24 4 weeks of gestation due to insufficient cervical cerclage, Enterococcus faecium was isolated from direct culture.

For another woman enrolled with PPROM and delivering at 32 2 gestational weeks because of persistent labour, subculture from thioglycollate broth showed growth of Enterococcus faecalis and Staphylococcus hominis whereas direct culture remained negative.
In all 26 cases of the control group, molecular techniques were negative.
Direct culture of microbial swabs on agar plates was also negative for all 26 women.

div.head: Correlation between detection of microorganisms and histopathological findings

p.s: In the preterm subgroup I, the histopathological examination of placenta and fetal membranes showed moderate to severe chorioamnionitis for 18 women.
In cases no. 2 and no.
14, no histopathological signs of infection or inflammation were found.
Both women had PPROM at enrolment.
They developed persistent preterm labour and a discretely increasing white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, leading to caesarean section.
In the preterm subgroup II, the placenta and fetal membranes of all 11 women yielded no histopathological evidence of inflammation.
In the control group, the histopathology of placenta and fetal membranes did not provide any sign of inflammation for 24 women, including those with positive subculture.

div.head: Association between microbial results and clinical data

p.s: Escherichia coli, Candida spp., Klebsiella spp.
and S. aureus were most frequently cultured from prepartum vaginal swabs in the preterm group (Table 3).
Ureaplasma spp.
and species from the streptococci group were not detected by routine culture techniques.
Prepartum antibiotic treatment was administered in 28 out of 31 cases in the preterm group, usually cefuroxime and metronidazole.

Neonatal infections (systemic inflammatory response syndrome, pneumonia) and postoperative maternal infectious complications (endometritis, fever, wound infection) occurred in seven cases of the total study population.
All seven women belonged to the preterm subgroup I, and microorganisms were detected by molecular techniques in maternal tissue in all cases.
The neonates of cases no.
6, 10 and 11 had positive blood cultures with growth of E. coli and S. aureus, respectively, as was detected by molecular and cultural methods in the maternal tissues.
In case no. 5, the neonate developed pneumonia with radiological signs of Ureaplasma infection although culture remained negative.

We did not find any clinical differences between the women with Ureaplasma or infections due to other microorganisms, regarding clinical symptoms, time between admission and delivery, or twin pregnancies versus singleton pregnancies.
However, this may be because of the small study group investigated.

The combination of two molecular techniques, broad range 16S rRNA-gene PCR and FISH, succeeded in identification of microorganisms in 11 out of 20 women with a clinical diagnosis of acute chorioamnionitis leading to preterm birth.
FISH visualized monospecies bacterial invasion deeply into the placental tissue and widespread on the surface of fetal membranes.
High concordance was shown with the histopathological finding of chorioamnionitis.
Neonatal infections and postoperative maternal infectious complications occurred only in this patient group.

The correlation of microbial and histopathological findings with the clinical data leads to the assumption that the species identified are the clinically relevant causative agents, playing a key role in the aetiology of chorioamnionitis in these cases.
In this context, the most important finding seems to be the high prevalence of Ureaplasma spp. as a leading cause of chorioamnionitis in preterm birth in our study (5 out of 20 cases).

There is growing evidence of a connection between the presence of Ureaplasma spp. in the vaginal microflora, combined with bacterial vaginosis or cervical incompetence, and adverse pregnancy outcome and neonatal morbidities [24,25].
The data of the present study correspond to the detection rates of Ureaplasma spp. in women with PPROM or preterm labour by amplification-based methods [5,26].
However, molecular techniques cannot so far be regarded as microbial routine diagnostic procedures in this field.
Ureaplasma spp.
are small microorganisms and cannot be identified by specific FISH probes so far.
However, their mostly intracellular habitat makes their appearance clearly identifiable.
Culture is the reference standard for detection of Ureaplasma spp., although specific media, cultivation for up to 7 days and technical expertise are required [24].

Routine culture methods in our microbiological department did not include these appropriate growth conditions and were not successful for detection of Ureaplasma spp. in any case of the present study, including culture of prepartum vaginal swabs.
This is alarming, especially considering the fact that Ureaplasma spp.
are naturally resistant to b-lactam antibiotics, representing the first-line therapy for women with PPROM.
Macrolides or clindamycin may constitute an alternative treatment, although studies concerning effective therapy are ongoing [27].
Therefore, thorough investigation for Ureaplasma by culture or molecular techniques should be mandatory in chorioamnionitis.
All samples from the term control group remained negative by PCR, FISH and direct culture.
Growth of Staphylococcus epidermidis and Lactobacillus rhamnosus after enrichment in liquid broth in two cases is most likely due to contamination.
Interpretation of the case with growth of S. aureus by enrichment culture is questionable.

The normal clinical course and absence of any sign of infection in the histopathological examination implies that potential colonization of placental tissue and fetal membranes by S. aureus remained subclinical in this case.

However, only five specimens from placental tissue, fetal membranes and umbilical cord from each woman were analysed by molecular techniques, whereas cultural swabs covered a larger area of the placenta.
This may also explain the results in one case of preterm subgroup II with isolation of E. faecium from direct culture, contrasting with negative FISH and PCR results.
In summary, it can be concluded that the established experimental protocol and the strict inclusion criteria regarding the delivery mode minimized the risk of contamination.

The presence of polymicrobial infections, as described before, seems unlikely because only single-species infections were observed in FISH and also sequencing after pan-bacterial amplification did not raise suspicion for multi-species infections.
However, polymicrobial infections cannot be excluded by the two molecular techniques applied in this study.
Jones et al. [9] suggest using species-specific real-time assays to increase sensitivity of the broad range amplification approach.
On the other hand, the direct visualization of microorganisms in situ allows verification of inconclusive results from culture or amplification-based techniques.
It shows spatial distribution of microorganisms and may help to elucidate the key species involved and the route of invasion of the amniotic cavity [28e30].

In conclusion, the combination of FISH and broad range 16S rRNA-gene PCR succeeded in definite identification of the causative microorganisms in 11 out of 20 cases with acute chorioamnionitis after PPROM and preterm labour leading to preterm birth.
The study protocol established minimizes risk of contamination.
The high prevalence of Ureaplasma spp., missed by routine microbial techniques, should lead to re-evaluation of diagnostic tools and therapeutic consequences.

A future prospective study combining prepartum Ureaplasma screening with postpartum molecular analysis for chorioamnionitis could identify those women who would benefit from targeted antibiotic treatment.
In case no. 2, the woman was allergic to penicillin.
In case no. 9, the decision for antibiotic treatment with ampicillin/sulbactam was not conclusive retrospectively.
Patients no. 13 and 15 received several prepartum antibiotic treatments.
Patient no.
20 was treated with cervical cerclage and received ampicillin/sulbactam perioperatively.
Fig. 1.
Ureaplasma parvum in placenta and fetal membranes in two women.
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis of placenta and fetal membrane tissue visualized Ureaplasma spp.
using the pan-bacterial probe EUB338 CY3 (orange) and the nucleic acid stain DAPI (blue), revealing small intracellular microorganisms of the expected morphology and size of 0.1e1 mm diameter.
Specific real-time PCR subsequently identified the bacteria as U. parvum.
(a) Overview of placental tissue with an overlay of CY3 (orange), FITC (green, background) and DAPI (blue) filter sets shows scattered Ureaplasma spp.
within the tissue.
No signal of the nonsense probe NON338 CY5 is detected in magenta.
The inset is a higher magnification of the area marked showing mostly intracellular bacteria surrounding host cell nuclei.
(b) Massive infection of the fetal membranes of another woman with Ureaplasma spp. as shown in the overlay of CY3 (orange), FITC (green) and DAPI (blue) filter sets.
No signal of the nonsense probe NON338 CY5 is detected in magenta.
Fig. 2. Detection of Staphylococcus aureus in fetal membranes.
A section of a fetal membrane specimen was hybridized with STAPHY FITC (green), SAU CY3 (orange), NON338 CY5 (magenta) and stained with the nucleic acid stain DAPI (blue).
(a) Overview: overlay of all filter sets shows Staphylococcus aureus biofilms consisting of STAPHY-and SAU-positive bacteria (yellow in overlay) within the fetal membrane.
No signal of the nonsense probe NON338 is detected in magenta.
(b) Higher magnification of the inset marked in (a).
Characteristics of the study populationData are shown as range (mean value) or n (%).
Clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis was defined by persistent labour in combination with at least one of the following criteria: maternal fever (>38.0
C), rising white blood cell count and C-reactive protein or fetal tachycardia (>160 beats/min).
Women were included consecutively, with the preterm group being recruited between August 2011 and June 2013 and the control group from April to June 2013.

Clinical data for preterm subgroup I (cases with delivery due to clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis, n ¼ 20) PPROM, preterm premature rupture of membranes; SIRS, systemic inflammatory response syndrome.

p.s: We thank the medical team of the Department of Obstetrics at Charit e University Medicine Berlin for supporting the sample collection.
The microscope was a donation by the Sonnenfeld-Stiftung Berlin, Germany.
We also thank Anne Gale for editorial assistance.
The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
